sentence.text: What makes balls and rockets and everything else move?
A force is needed to start an object moving, to stop it from moving, or to change direction.
A force is like a push or a pull.
When you pull the boat by the rope, the pulling force starts the boat moving.
What makes balls and rockets and everything else move?
A force is needed to start an object moving, to stop it from moving, or to change direction.
A force is like a push or a pull.
When you pull the boat by the rope, the pulling force starts the boat moving.
And when you push the small rocket, the pushing force starts the rocket moving.
Sir Isaac Newton discovered three laws of motion 350 years ago.
These three laws work for objects on Earth and for objects in space.
They even work for the moon, the sun, and the stars!.
That Isaac Newton was very smart.
And when you push the small rocket, the pushing force starts the rocket moving.
Sir Isaac Newton discovered three laws of motion 350 years ago.
These three laws work for objects on Earth and for objects in space.
They even work for the moon, the sun, and the stars!.
That Isaac Newton was very smart.
Here is part of Newton's First Law.
A moving object keeps moving in the same direction and at the same speed.
Only when a force (a push or pull) is added does the object change direction or speed.
The small rocket keeps moving at the same speed in the same direction.
Here is part of Newton's First Law.
A moving object keeps moving in the same direction and at the same speed.
Only when a force (a push or pull) is added does the object change direction or speed.
The small rocket keeps moving at the same speed in the same direction.
A moving object keeps moving in the same direction and at the same speed until a force pushes or pulls on the object to change its direction or speed.
If you push the rocket up, the force changes the rocket's direction.
You can add a new force that changes the direction of the rocket again by pushing it down.
When you push the rocket backward, the new force slows down the rocket.
A new force can speed up a rocket, slow down a rocket, or change the direction.
If you push the rocket up, the force changes the rocket's direction.
You can add a new force that changes the direction of the rocket again by pushing it down.
When you push the rocket backward, the new force slows down the rocket.
A new force can speed up a rocket, slow down a rocket, or change the direction.
When you push the rocket backward, you can see how the new force slows down the rocket.
And, if the rocket is stopped, it stays still until another force is added.
Here is the complete First Law.
Moving objects keep moving in the same direction and at the same speed until a force is added, and stopped objects remain still until a force is added.
And, if the rocket is stopped, it stays still until another force is added.
Here is the complete First Law.
Moving objects keep moving in the same direction and at the same speed until a force is added, and stopped objects remain still until a force is added.
Moving objects keep moving in the same direction and at the same speed until a force is added.
Stopped objects remain still until a force is added.
Juan kicks the ball on the grass.
Juan added a force to start the ball rolling, but why did it stop.
The grass rubs on the ball.
That rubbing is a force called friction, and friction is the force that slows the ball.
Juan kicks the ball on the grass.
Juan added a force to start the ball rolling, but why did it stop.
The grass rubs on the ball.
That rubbing is a force called friction, and friction is the force that slows the ball.
Juan added a force to start the ball rolling.
But why did it stop.
The grass rubs on the ball.
That rubbing is a force called friction.
Friction is the force that slows the ball.
The grass rubs on the ball creating a rubbing force called friction, which slows the ball.
Maria picks up the ball, and then she throws the ball in the air .
Why does the ball fall to the ground.
Gravity pulls it down.
Gravity is the force that pulls together objects like the ball and Earth.
Maria picks up the ball, and then she throws the ball in the air .
Why does the ball fall to the ground.
Gravity pulls it down.
Gravity is the force that pulls together objects like the ball and Earth.
Maria picks up the ball. She throws the ball in the air.
The First Law says that objects keep moving in the same direction until a force is added.
On Earth, friction and gravity are forces that can change speed and direction of objects.
In space, there is no friction and only a little gravity.
So, objects in space, like the moon, keep moving for a very, very long time!.
The First Law says that objects keep moving in the same direction until a force is added.
On Earth, friction and gravity are forces that can change speed and direction of objects.
In space, there is no friction and only a little gravity.
So, objects in space, like the moon, keep moving for a very, very long time!.
On Earth, friction and gravity are forces that can change speed and direction of objects, but in space, there is no friction and only a little gravity.
Acceleration is when something goes faster and faster.
When you run, you begin by accelerating; and when a car speeds up, it accelerates.
Newton's Second Law says that the amount of acceleration depends on the amount of force and the weight of the object.
Acceleration is when something goes faster and faster.
When you run, you begin by accelerating; and when a car speeds up, it accelerates.
Newton's Second Law says that the amount of acceleration depends on the amount of force and the weight of the object.
When you run, you begin by accelerating.
When a car speeds up, it accelerates.
When you give a little push to the little rocket, it starts to move.
Going from no movement to some movement is acceleration.
If you give a little push to the big rocket, it starts to move, but more slowly.
When you give a little push to the little rocket, it starts to move.
Going from no movement to some movement is acceleration.
If you give a little push to the big rocket, it starts to move, but more slowly.
If you give a little push to the big rocket, you'll see that it starts to move, but more slowly.
Newton's Second Law is: A little force will accelerate a light object, but a big force is needed to accelerate a heavy object the same amount.
So, to get the big rocket to accelerate more, you'll need to keep pushing it to add a big force.
If you push it enough, it will start to go as fast as the little rocket.
Newton's Second Law is: A little force will accelerate a light object, but a big force is needed to accelerate a heavy object the same amount.
So, to get the big rocket to accelerate more, you'll need to keep pushing it to add a big force.
If you push it enough, it will start to go as fast as the little rocket.
You'll need to keep pushing the rocket to add a big force.
This will make the rocket accelerate more.

story.title: Newton's Law of Acceleration on Earth

sentence.text: Juan ties the dog to the cart.
The dog pulls the cart to Maria.
The dog adds a force to accelerate the cart.
Maria piles wood into the cart.
Now the cart is so heavy that the dog can only accelerate it a tiny amount.
Juan ties the dog to the cart.
The dog pulls the cart to Maria.
The dog adds a force to accelerate the cart.
Maria piles wood into the cart.
Now the cart is so heavy that the dog can only accelerate it a tiny amount.
Juan ties the dog to the cart, and the dog pulls the cart to Maria.
Maria piles wood into the cart, which makes the cart so heavy that the dog can only accelerate it a tiny amount.

story.title: Newton's Law of Acceleration on Earth

sentence.text: Maria unties the dog and brings a horse to the cart.
The horse can pull the cart to Juan because the horse adds a bigger force.
The big force accelerates the cart and gets it moving.
When the horse stops pulling, the cart stops.
Friction is the force that stops the cart.
Maria unties the dog and brings a horse to the cart.
The horse can pull the cart to Juan because the horse adds a bigger force.
The big force accelerates the cart and gets it moving.
When the horse stops pulling, the cart stops.
Friction is the force that stops the cart.
Maria unties the dog.
She brings a horse to the cart.
The big force accelerates the cart and gets it moving, but when the horse stops pulling, the cart stops.

story.title: Newton's Third Law: Forces are Paired

sentence.text: Newton's Third Law says that a force in one direction is always paired with a force in the other direction.
Maria and Sara get on their skateboards.
Maria pushes Sara.
Sara moves forward, but Maria goes backward!.
Newton's Third Law says that a force in one direction is always paired with a force in the other direction.
Maria and Sara get on their skateboards.
Maria pushes Sara.
Sara moves forward, but Maria goes backward!.
When Maria pushes Sara, Sara moves forward, but Maria goes backward!.

story.title: Newton's Third Law: Forces are Paired

sentence.text: The force of Maria's push on Sara is paired with a force pushing Maria back.
That is why she goes backward.
Juan climbs into the boat.
He puts the paddle into the water and pushes the water backward.
The water moves backward, but the boat moves forward!.
The force of Maria's push on Sara is paired with a force pushing Maria back.
That is why she goes backward.
Juan climbs into the boat.
He puts the paddle into the water and pushes the water backward.
The water moves backward, but the boat moves forward!.
Maria goes backward because the force of Maria's push on Sara is paired with a force pushing Maria back.

story.title: Newton's Third Law: Forces are Paired

sentence.text: The force of pushing the water backward is paired with the forward force of the water on the paddle.
And that pushes the boat forward.
A force in one direction is always paired with an equal force in the other direction.
The force of pushing the water backward is paired with the forward force of the water on the paddle.
And that pushes the boat forward.
A force in one direction is always paired with an equal force in the other direction.
The force of pushing the water backward is paired with the forward force of the water on the paddle, which pushes the boat forward.

story.title: Newton's Third Law: Forces are Paired

sentence.text: A pair of forces make rockets move in space.
Flames shoot out from the back of the rocket.
Then, the rocket moves forward.
Because forces are paired, for every action in one direction, there is always a reaction in the other direction.
A pair of forces make rockets move in space.
Flames shoot out from the back of the rocket.
Then, the rocket moves forward.
Because forces are paired, for every action in one direction, there is always a reaction in the other direction.
When flames shoot out from the back of the rocket, the rocket moves forward.
Maria gets on her skateboard.
To get moving, she needs a force (First Law).
She pushes backward on the ground with one foot.
This makes the skateboard move forward (Law of Paired Forces).
Maria gets on her skateboard.
To get moving, she needs a force (First Law).
She pushes backward on the ground with one foot.
This makes the skateboard move forward (Law of Paired Forces).
She pushes backward on the ground with one foot, which makes the skateboard move forward (Law of Paired Forces).
Maria starts down a hill.
The force of gravity pulls the skateboard down the hill faster and faster (Law of Acceleration).
Oh no, a toy truck moves onto the road.
The toy truck stops the skateboard, but Maria keeps going.
Maria keeps going because objects in motion stay in motion (First Law).
Maria starts down a hill.
The force of gravity pulls the skateboard down the hill faster and faster (Law of Acceleration).
Oh no, a toy truck moves onto the road.
The toy truck stops the skateboard, but Maria keeps going.
Maria keeps going because objects in motion stay in motion (First Law).
Maria stops when friction from the ground adds a force to stop her.
The First Law explains why it is important to wear a seatbelt in the car.
When the car stops, you keep moving just like Maria.
The seatbelt adds a force to stop you and keep you safe.
Maria stops when friction from the ground adds a force to stop her.

The seatbelt adds a force to stop you and keep you safe.
